title: First Came Giuliani’s Input on the Immigration Order. Now There’s the Court Test.
text:
No specific religion is mentioned in the executive order, which was issued on Jan. 27, but the appeals court said it must examine evidence that the order was meant to carry out a Muslim ban.

That would include an interview Mr. Giuliani gave the day after it was issued. Speaking to Fox News, he cast himself as the architect.

Asked if the new order had anything to do with religion, Mr. Giuliani held forth on how it had been devised and what he said had been his role in carrying out Mr. Trump’s wishes.

“I’ll tell you the whole history of it,” Mr. Giuliani said on Fox. “So when he first announced it, he said, ‘Muslim ban.’ He called me up and said, ‘Put a commission together, show me the right way to do it legally.’”

By focusing the order not on religion but on areas of the world that created danger for the United States, Mr. Giuliani said, the ban is “perfectly sensible, perfectly legal.”

Now federal courts are considering if the order is, in fact, “perfectly legal.”

Congress and the Constitution give a president broad control over the country’s borders. One explicit limit is that a president may not refuse immigrants visas because of their race, sex, nationality, place of birth or residence.

August Flentje, a lawyer from the Department of Justice, argued this week before the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit that judges cannot try to find out if a president disguised some of the reasons for an executive order. The “best evidence” of the president’s intent is the language of the order, he said, adding: “That is the end of the inquiry.”

The State of Washington, and others challenging the order, argue that it was an illegal ban of Muslims, papered over with reasons that the law permits.

And that is where Mr. Giuliani’s remarks come in. Until his interview, Mr. Giuliani — the former mayor of New York, former candidate for the United States Senate and former candidate for president — had largely fallen into eclipse following a spectacular run of appearances on behalf of Mr. Trump during the campaign.

In October, Mr. Giuliani boasted of having inside information from F.B.I. agents and promised a late-game surprise that would damage the campaign of Hillary Clinton, the Democratic opponent of Mr. Trump. “We’ve got a couple of things up our sleeve that should turn this thing around,” he said.

Indeed, 11 days before the election, the F.B.I. director announced that the agency was looking into emails that had been found on a laptop used by the estranged husband of an aide to Mrs. Clinton. Although the F.B.I. eventually said nothing in the emails warranted prosecution, the political damage had been done to the Clinton campaign.

During arguments this week, the lawyer from the Department of Justice seemed to scoff at citations from news reports of remarks by Mr. Trump and Mr. Giuliani.

“It is extraordinary for a court to enjoin the president’s national security determination based on some newspaper articles,” Mr. Flentje said.

Judge Richard R. Clifton, a member of the appeals panel who was nominated to the bench by President George W. Bush, wanted clarification.

“Do you deny that in fact the statements attributed to then-candidate Trump and to his political advisers, and most recently Mr. Giuliani — do you deny that those statements were made?” Judge Clifton asked.

Mr. Flentje suggested that campaign statements were not the right place to look for the president’s intent.

Judge Clifton said the words mattered: “Either those kinds of statements were made, or they’re not.”
